title: Sophie Turner & Archie Madekwe On The â€œDangersâ€ Of Excessive Wealth Hoarding By Billionaires
text:
Sophie Turner & Archie Madekwe On The â€œDangersâ€ Of Excessive Wealth Hoarding By Billionaires

Sophie Turner and Archie Madekweâ€™s newest Prime Video show Steal centers around a major heist where billions of pounds are stolen from a London pension fund. Without giving any spoilers (thereâ€™s a lot of twists revealed throughout the show), the series broadly focuses on how much wealth in society is controlled by a small percentage of people, how it affects all of us workers in the capitalist regime, and what lengths people will go to for money.

Turner plays Zara, your regular office worker who barely earns a living wage while working at a swanky office in Londonâ€™s wealthy financial district. The show depicts the fallout after thieves hold the office workers hostage and steal billions of pounds from peopleâ€™s pensions. As Zara and her friend Luke (Madekwe) try to solve the mystery, things get complicated, and lives are at stake.

Madekwe tells Refinery29 itâ€™s â€œvery dangerousâ€ to have so much wealth controlled by so few people, which he believes Steal conveys well. â€œItâ€™s incredibly prevalent right nowâ€¦ I think the show kind of explores that in a lot of ways, but of course, itâ€™s awful,â€ the actor says. â€œI think people can relate to [the show]. I think everybody is feeling [stuck], you know? And everybody feels helpless, and there are people [who] could change the situation, and donâ€™tâ€¦ the disparity [in wealth] is huge, and it isnâ€™t fair. And yeah, itâ€™s anarchic.â€

Turner adds that Steal shows how desperation, when it comes to money, can push people to the limit. â€œWeâ€™ve got too many billionaires and the cost-of-living crisis [means] the disparity is too big, and the gapâ€™s got to close. I wish I could do something about it, but I just canâ€™t,â€ she says. â€œBut thatâ€™s what I like about the show, as well. It explores why good people do bad things, and it is for reasons like this. So thatâ€™s what I love, exploring that.â€

For Turner, sheâ€™s previously played fantasy characters like Sansa Stark (Game of Thrones), Jean Grey (X-Men: Apocalpyse) and more recently, 1980s character Joan (Joan). Itâ€™s no surprise that for a show tackling topics like wealth inequality, her role as Zara in Steal hits closer to home, with family trauma, a messy love life, and other relatable traits. But rather than missing an extravagant wardrobe or hours in makeup, she relished the chance to tell a story in a different way. â€œI donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve ever played a character quite as messy as her and it was really fun because I felt like I could just show up.. itâ€™s just very relieving when you donâ€™t have to wear a corset and your shoulders arenâ€™t pulled back, you donâ€™t have to talk in a certain way,â€ Turner says. â€œI could just kind of flop about, I donâ€™t know how else to explain it. I felt so free in playing her, I think thatâ€™s what I mean,â€ she adds. â€œ[Sheâ€™s the] closest to me as any character Iâ€™ve played.â€

While her character Zara is more ordinary than most others sheâ€™s stepped into, being held at gunpoint is anything but. While youâ€™d imagine being put through your paces by masked thieves would be taxing, Turner actually just saw that action-packed day as another day in the officeâ€¦ literally. â€œI really thrive on days when it is a high-stakes day where itâ€™s a lot of drama and a lot of emotion, and I actually find it quite cathartic,â€ the actor says. â€œI go home feeling much better about myself than I did walking in. I think thatâ€™s what acting is for me, is therapy. I always feel better going home and itâ€™s easy to step out of it.â€

And even though the actors might not take home the anxiety or emotions from set, Stealâ€™s fast-paced show could very well induce it in viewers. But Madekwe notes thatâ€™s the reason viewers watch heist shows in the first place. â€œItâ€™s like fun, escapism,â€ he explains. â€œI always love [watching] things that make me kind of physically feel something. And if something gets your heart racing, kind of builds anxiety in that way like a show like this does, and youâ€™re able to create that in your own home, then I think itâ€™s so exciting. And this show, I think, really succeeds with that.â€

All six episodes of Steal will be able to stream on Amazon Prime Video on January 21, 2026.

title: These Shoulder-Length Haircuts Are Anything But Boring, Say Top Hairstylists
text:
These Shoulder-Length Haircuts Are Anything But Boring, Say Top Hairstylists

From the bob to the bixie, short haircuts have become the style of choice in salons up and down the country. Though they all look incredible, theyâ€™re also pretty high maintenance.Â 

For those who donâ€™t like the idea of booking in for a monthly trim, a midi, shoulder-length cut might be your best bet. Far from mediocre, the in-between length isnâ€™t only much easier to keep sharp â€” itâ€™s also being touted as one of the biggest hair trends for 2026. â€œMid-length cuts donâ€™t have to feel like a long, grown-out bob,â€ says Jordan Jones, stylist and color technician at Taylor Taylor London. â€œThis year, weâ€™re being shown that they can be their own style with layers and careful shaping to create volume and movement, or shine and sophistication. If your bob has grown out and your hair has reached that awkward-length stage, or if youâ€™ve got long locks and fancy a change without going super short, a trendy mid-length style is the cut for you.â€

On Instagram, Londonâ€™s most sought-after stylists The Hair Bros are also championing shoulder-length haircuts with curtain bangs, concave layers, and natural waves. It seems weâ€™ve all got the same idea: Google search for shoulder-length haircuts has risen by 180% recently.

So what should you ask for? â€œA choppy cut with plenty of layers that frame the face and create soft movement,â€ says Jones. â€œThink Billie Eilish and Miley Cyrusâ€™s shaggy â€˜dos.â€ Jones says the look works well with any hair texture. â€œSea salt products are a must-have to give an effortless, freshly tousled finishing touch.â€ Take inspiration from this look by Francesca Inverarity.

The Flip

The Hair Bros say a shoulder-length cut is its own style and that itâ€™s important not to leave all of the hair one length. â€œThis will end up looking heavy, as if it were a shorter bob. A middy haircut should be full of texture and life and feel fun and playful. Itâ€™s great for anyone who wants to cut their long hair short but isnâ€™t quite ready to brave a bob.â€ Flip your hair to one side for more of a natural, lived-in feel, like this cut on Alexia Colombo. â€œAs always, just a few products and some air should be enough to style this cut,â€ added The Hair Bros.

title: The Best Performances Of The Year Were Black
text:
The Best Performances Of The Year Were Black

Welcome to â€œWhatâ€™s Good,â€ a column where we break down whatâ€™s soothing, distracting, or just plain good in Hollywood with a â€œrooting for everybody Blackâ€ energy. These are the best onscreen performances of 2025 by Black performers.Â 

The headline of my end-of-year column hasnâ€™t changed since I started compiling the best of the best in film a few years ago. The Best Performances of 2025 are Black, just like they were in 2024 and 2023, and so on. Black performers consistently raise the bar. They are great because they have to be, and especially in a year when we saw Hollywood roll back DEI commitments and descend into a hellscape where Black actors had to defend themselves from being called â€œDEI hiresâ€ for simply working while Black, these performances cut through the noise and let the work speak for itself.Â 

In 2025, there were so many Black performers who met the challenge of being excellent in the face of an industry that is actively trying to erase them. They took the gravity (or levity) of their material and elevated what was on the page to make it even better. In a year that tested us all â€” seriously, we barely survived â€” through their work these artists gave us so much, a reprieve from the hellscape of our social feeds and portrayals of the human experience that revealed a little more about ourselves. Every awards season, I remind you that while weâ€™ve long since divested from the gatekeeping archaic institutions that consistently exclude Black folks from legacy awards, giving recognition where itâ€™s due still matters.Â 

When Sinners was undoubtedly (when it came to box office performance and cultural impact) the movie of the year, and yet still is left off of multiple (white) criticsâ€™ year-end lists and awards predictions, itâ€™s more and more evident that we need to uplift our own (letâ€™s not forget that winning an NAACP Image Award should be just as big of an honor as getting an Oscar). We must acknowledge the best Black performances beyond the one or two actors that legacy awards deem worthy of being their annual token, albeit deserved, inclusions. We refuse to settle for crumbs. We get to exist in a timeline where a multitude of Black artistic expressions are celebrated. â€˜Tis the season to look back on the best of the best of the year and the best, as always, is Black as hell â€” whether they get accolades from certain governing bodies or not.

These are the performances Iâ€™ve been yelling at you about all year. So, here is my exhaustive, definitive, and still not long enough list of 2025â€™s best Black film performances.Â 

Michael B. Jordan, SinnersÂ 

Five years ago, I wrote a piece called â€œShouldnâ€™t Michael B. Jordan Have An Oscar Nomination By Now?.â€ In it, I argued that Jordan was long overdue for a nomination for an Academy Award. In 2020, the MBJ role in contention was his performance as real-life social justice lawyer Bryan Stevenson in Just Mercy. Despite being one of the most famous, talented, bankable heartthrobs in Hollywood, he hasnâ€™t garnered the same accolades his contemporaries of past generations had at his age (see DiCaprio, Damon, Cruise, Pitt). It may be five years late, but Jordan is finally in contention for a Best Actor nod for his portrayal of Smoke and Stack, the prodigal twins of Sinners. I bring up Jordanâ€™s awards chances not because I think a nomination or win would impact the quality of his work, but because after these performances, he deserves every accolade available to him in this industry. As Smoke and Stack, Jordan shows off range many of his detractors will swear he doesnâ€™t have. In each scene, with a tilt of his head or the looseness of his swagger, Jordan carves out each twinâ€™s mannerisms uniquely enough that you are rooting for Smoke while holding your breath waiting for Stack to mess things up, and subtly enough that itâ€™s clear the brothers are inseparable and to an untrained eye, sometimes indecipherable.Â 

It takes a lot of skill to carry an ambitious masterpiece like Sinners. And to put it simply, the film does not work without the precision and thoughtfulness of Jordanâ€™s performances. Weâ€™ve been watching him grow as an actor since he was coming of age in All My Children, The Wire, and Friday Night Lights, to young powerhouse showings in Fruitvale Station and Creed. Then, there were the bonafide blockbusters in Creed II and Black Panther. Jordan has proven â€” repeatedly â€“Â  that heâ€™s earned his status as a Movie Star. Sinners is proof heâ€™s done something so many of his peers only dream of: reached his potential and surpassed it.

Cynthia Erivo, Wicked: For GoodÂ 

Yes, I am one of the few critics who actually liked Wicked: For Good. I stand by my review of the film, which argued that while the movie is the weaker half in the two-part adaptation of the Broadway musical, it did right by its source material and delivered a thrilling, emotional, and endearing conclusion. And about Erivo, who is undoubtedly the best Elphaba of all time, I wrote, â€œmany headlines about Wicked: For Good have focused on Ariana Grande, and while itâ€™s true she is great in this sequel and that itâ€™s more Glindaâ€™s movie than Elphabaâ€™s, Erivo is still firing on all cylinders, delivering a timeless performance that is also worthy of unadulterated praise. Throughout Wicked: For Good, Elphaba goes from fugitive freedom fighter, to heartbroken friend and exasperated sister, to frustrated revolutionary, to lover in mourning, to resigned martyr. Itâ€™s a depressing arc that sees the optimism of progressivism dashed with a big dose of witch-melting water. The simplicity of the message â€” that doing good comes at a cost, that no matter your intentions, things donâ€™t always work in your favor, and that facism may take on a new face but itâ€™s an ever-present threat â€” is the point.â€Â 

The Wicked instalments are going to go down in history as two of the biggest movies of this decade, if not the century, and that will largely be because Cynthia Erivo gave us an unforgettable and undeniable Elphaba.

Tessa Thompson, HeddaÂ 

Not to keep quoting myself but this is what I wrote about Hedda in my review back in October: â€œSet in 1950s England, as the party devolves into shambles â€” mostly orchestrated by Hedda herself â€” Hedda goes from a simmering conversation about what happens to a woman bound by her circumstances to a sexy psychological thriller about class, power, and ambition. As the events of the evening unfold, Hedda becomes more and more quietly unhinged and Tessa Thompson is so magnetic, oozing with charisma, that you canâ€™t look away and you canâ€™t help but root for one of the messiest women in cinematic history. I like to think of this column as my own Oscars. The Academy is going to deem their own â€œbest of the bestâ€ come March 2026, and while Tessa Thompsonâ€™s name should definitely be on that ballot, in this space, I get to say whatâ€™s the best of the year and I am telling you â€” unequivocally â€” that Hedda is one of the best films and performances of the past year. Period.â€Â

Wunmi Mosaku, SinnersÂ 

As mentioned above, SinnersÂ is Michael B. Jordanâ€™s showcase. But itâ€™s more than just a vehicle for MBJâ€™s movie stardom or a Southern gothic horror flick like itâ€™s been billed. It is that, but itâ€™s also an enthusiastic musical, a consequential period drama, and an earnest romance. Itâ€™s the latter that piqued my interest the most, and its execution is swoon-inducing. I already knew Wunmi Mosaku was a star, but in this role, sheâ€™s assertive, luminous and so damn sexy. Annie is the heart ofÂ Sinners. Sheâ€™s also its hero.Â Â â€œI like to think of Annie as Smokeâ€™s other other half, like Stack is,â€ Mosaku said when we interviewed her in April. â€œStack is one side of him, but Annie is another side of him. Sheâ€™s his protector, lover, mother, safe place. She is his sanctuary.â€ Annieâ€™s knowledge of the spiritual world also saves everyoneâ€™s â€” including Smokeâ€™s â€” asses. â€œShe moves with purpose. She moves with strength and power. She has such an anchored spirit and is so in tune with the other stuff that we canâ€™t see or feel or hear. She sees and feels and hears it.â€

Ayo Edebiri, After The Hunt

Iâ€™m ready to be right about After The Hunt. It might take a few years, but I swear this film will outlive its discourse. The Luca Guadagnino-directed drama documents a moment in time â€” a disturbing, delicate, and awkward moment in time, one that we are still navigating. And for better or worse, shouldnâ€™t we have art that reflects these times? Thatâ€™s what I wrote at the time of the filmâ€™s release and I stand by it: â€œWith time, After The Hunt may hold up as a page to be read in the chapter of this so-called cultural reckoning. Think of it as a sleek and uncomfortable time capsule of the past half decade of #MeToo discourse, or as a character study of flawed intellectuals desperately attempting to perform their values while clinging to the facade of their respective identities. Or, as Ayo Edebiri told me, After The Hunt is a â€œRorschach testâ€ that interrogates your discomfort.

And itâ€™s in that discomfort where Edebiri and the rest of the cast (Andrew Garfield and Julia Roberts are both excellent as usual) shine. If youâ€™ve seen The Bear or Bottoms, you know Edebiri is a star who can play awkward better than anyone. It was this role that reminded me that sheâ€™s going to be around for a very long time. Going toe-to-toe with icon Roberts without flinching and sparring effortlessly with Oscar nominee Garfield, Edebiri in After The Hunt is one of those star-making performances that weâ€™ll look back on in awe.

David Jonsson, The Long Walk

David Jonsson doesnâ€™t get enough credit for being one of the most exciting and talented working actors of his generation. I officially fell in love with him in Rye Lane, one of the best rom-coms of the past decade, and this year, he showed versatility and depth in his choices. In The Long Walk, Jonsson anchors the filmâ€™s brutal premise: a near-future America where teenage boys volunteer for a televised endurance contest that demands they keep walking above the minimum speed or face lethal consequences. Jonssonâ€™s performance is achingly vulnerable. As the miles stack up and the rules tighten (three warnings, then youâ€™re shot), Jonsson charts the slow erosion of bravado into something far more fragile.

As realization sets in that survival isnâ€™t just about strong legs, itâ€™s about memory, friendship, and the will to keep choosing the next step, Jonsson is especially magnetic in the quieter stretches, trading jokes with fellow walkers (and delivering electric chemistry with Cooper Hoffman) at dawn, bargaining with himself as the road narrows, and letting grief and resolve flicker across his face when the crowdâ€™s cheers turn hollow. Rather than leaning into the spectacle of the contest, Jonsson makes the walk feel personal. With each warning comes a small heartbreak and each mile an excruciating decision. grounding the dystopia in intimacy and reminding us that the most powerful performances donâ€™t outrun the story; they walk straight through it.

Naomi Ackie, Mickey 17

Itâ€™s still baffling to me that Bong Joon Hoâ€™s Mickey 17 flopped because itâ€™s so weird and wonderful, and the kind of original movie from one of the greatest living directors that we need more of. But I refuse to let people forget about Naomi Ackieâ€™s performance as Nasha, the love interest to Pattinsonâ€™s aloof Mickey. Nasha is wild, extremely weird, and an enforcer in a futuristic universe where civilian space travel to another planet sets it apart from our current reality, but a psychotic tyrannical politician with a god complex (Mark Ruffaloâ€™s Kenneth Marshall) makes it feel eerily familiar.

Hereâ€™s what I wrote back in March: â€œWhileÂ Mickey 17Â is, by all accounts, a showcase of Pattinsonâ€™s unquantifiable talent, itâ€™s also a stunning display of how reliably formidableÂ Naomi AckieÂ is. Sheâ€™s one of the brightest talents working right now, and the weirder she gets, the more wonderful it is to watch. Mickey is clueless, compliant, and a bit dense. Nasha is clever, confident, and fearless. Nasha could easily be relegated to a girlfriend-of-the-hero stereotype, a disposable plot device, but in Bongâ€™s script, sheâ€™s assertive, motivated, and layered. And in Ackieâ€™s hands, Nasha leaps off the page and dazzles on screen.â€

Damson Idris, F1

After captivating audiences asÂ Franklin Saint inÂ Snowfall, Damson Idris had cemented himself as a young actor to watch in Hollywood. He shifted gears â€” literally â€” into high-octane territory with his leading role inÂ F1, the Formula 1 racing filmÂ from director Joseph Kosinski and co-starring Brad Pitt. I didnâ€™t love F1, but it was one of the biggest movies of the year and the things that do work about the film are thanks in large part to Idris, who brings charisma and surprising vulnerability to his portrayal of hotshot driver Joshua Pierce.

Whether heâ€™s embodying a South Central kingpin or donning a racing suit opposite Hollywood heavyweights, Idris brings depth, precision, and a quiet confidence that continues to set him apart. And as Unbotheredâ€™s very ownÂ Christa EduafoÂ found out when she sat down with him earlier this year in New York City, the actor is well aware that his Black female fanbase bet big on Damson Idris stock early. And with F1, itâ€™s clear our investment has paid off.

Chase Infiniti, Teyana Taylor & Regina Hall, One Battle After AnotherÂ 

The Black women characters in One Battle After Another have elicited divisive responses. Some critics have written off Teyana Taylorâ€™s Perfidia Beverly Hills as a sexualized stereotype with limited screen time and an underdeveloped character arc. In her Black Girl Watching Substack, Brooke Obie writes, â€œBlack women are little more than props and plot devicesâ€ and that â€œ[director Paul Thomas] Anderson isnâ€™t commenting on the white male fetishization of Black women, heâ€™s directly participating in it.â€ While Angelica Jade Bastien for Vulture says, â€œThe Black women of the film are lightning rods for the most forceful conversations the film can bear, and itâ€™s thrilling to watch them embody what Andersonâ€™s script can only loosely hold.â€

Thereâ€™s a lot to say about how Paul Thomas Anderson depicts Perfidia, Chase Infinitiâ€™s Willa, and Regina Hallâ€™s Deandra (I agree mostly with both Obie and Bastien and their reviews are required supplementary reading material post-watch of OBAA), but of all the critiques of the execution of the lofty ideas of revolution that PTA puts forth in the film, nothing negative can be said about the performances given by these three enigmatic actors. Infiniti is the breakout of the film, playing an almost grown up Willa (the daughter of DiCaprioâ€™s Pat and Taylorâ€™s Perfidia) with quiet resolve and appropriate teen angst. Itâ€™s one of the most stunning breakout performances Iâ€™ve ever seen and Infiniti should have her pick of roles in the aftermath of this movieâ€™s success.

As for Hall and Taylor, we knew how talented they were â€” though in different mediums: Taylor as an artist, dancer, and creative director and Hall as a comedic genius. In this film, even if I wish the material lived up to their efforts, both are able to showcase their abilities to give grounding, affecting, dramatic performances. Deandra and Perfidia are in conversation with each other, showing two sides of how to be a revolutionary, and Hall and Taylorâ€™s performances are striking. While Perfidia is loud, brash, emotional, reckless, and boisterous, Deandra is methodical, focused, and intentional. One Battle After Another has been hailed as PTAâ€™s greatest masterpiece and donâ€™t get me wrong, I do think the movie is a triumph, but letâ€™s be clear on why itâ€™s great: Chase Infiniti, Teyana Taylor and Regina Hall.

Edi Gathegi, Superman

Superman was one of my favorite movies of the year. And while the main cast trio of David Corenswet, Rachel Brosnahan, and Nicholas Hoult, Edi Gathegiâ€™s Mister Terrific was a surprising delight. Mister Terrific emerges as one of Supermanâ€™s smartest anchors, threading intellect through a story preoccupied with power, trust, and what the world expects its heroes to be. As the film tracks Clark Kent navigating a public increasingly skeptical of Supermanâ€™s unchecked strength â€” while Lex Luthorâ€™s machinations test the limits of truth, tech, and influence â€” Gathegiâ€™s Mister Terrific operates in the grey area where ethics meet engineering. Andre Holland, Love, Brooklyn

Andre Holland gives Rachael Abigail Holderâ€™s Love, Brooklyn its bruised, beating heart, turning a deceptively small story about dating in the city into something quietly expansive. Holland plays these emotional crosscurrents with exquisite restraint, letting hesitation, guilt, and longing flicker across his face before a single word lands. What makes his work so compelling is how deeply he understands the filmâ€™s thesis: that love isnâ€™t always about grand declarations, but about timing, honesty, and the courage to stop hiding in the in-between. In Hollandâ€™s hands, Roger is funny, charming, frustrating, and achingly recognizable; heâ€™s a man learning, step by step, how to choose presence over comfort.
